body: Just double test and it works fine. I gonna merge.

I just tested, works perfectly with Kafka 0.9.0.1. I suppose we need to update the documentation but I am not sure where is the right place. I will merge it as it is and we will look afterwards for the doc.
replaced the custom lengthaware coder by the existing one (prefix)

- finalize checkpoint and close the reader at end of reader.
- avoid invoking getWatermark() twice on the reader.

CI build fails with two errors, can you take a look?

2018-02-10T15:08:03.087 [INFO] org.apache.beam.sdk.extensions.sql.impl.BeamSqlEnv.deregisterTable(String) makes inefficient use of keySet iterator instead of entrySet iterator [org.apache.beam.sdk.extensions.sql.impl.BeamSqlEnv] At BeamSqlEnv.java:[line 102] WMI_WRONG_MAP_ITERATOR

Yes, I know quite well how SDF IOs are supposed to work. ðŸ˜ƒ 

However, I think that in properly unbounded pipelines the "discovery source" will also stay online forever. (I think of SDF IOs like this: "Discovery Source/DoFn" -> "Reader SDF", where for Kafka the discovery source would listen for new partitions on the topics and forward them as they come online, for Kinesis it would listen for new shards and for files it would listen for files)

Side note: I think the Beam Kafka IO does currently not discover new partitions when a pipeline is already running, which is a bit of a problem. Having the discovery source stay always online would solve this. Not sure about the Kinesis IO. Flink has a different problem: all parallel instances of a source query for new Kafka partitions/Kinesis Shards and they have a deterministic way of assigning them to the instances (basically modulo). This, however, will DDoS Kafka/Kinesis which also can lead to problems. SDF IOs would solve this problem because there is only one part that does the periodic querying for new shards/partitions. Also, the Flink File source has worked like a SDF IO for quite a while now but we have never generalised the pattern as in what we want to do with SDF IOs in Beam.

On your last point: we currently can't do this because then our tests would not terminate and also because "bounded streaming pipelines" (which sounds very strange) would not terminate.
Hi @kennknowles @pawel-kaczmarczyk, can you please take a look?

I will take a look at this on gradle once the support is finished. First I prefer to focus in the maven build since it has the full support for tests/etc. Maybe it is a good idea to ask to get Java 9 installed in the workers, at least to validate that compilation does not break, WDYT ? (Note we are still far from having all test passing, but for the moment only 4 tests in sdks/java/core break which is better than I expected).

Seems like a good idea to me to work in small increments. I think it does make sense to get Java 9 installed in parallel on the workers. I really would rather do containerized builds so we control the environment(s) but I don't think anyone has time for it.

Separate from this change, can you make a Java 9 maven and gradle build that just doesn't trigger automatically, only via "run java 9 tests" or something? That way we can share the results on PRs but it doesn't make things all go red.

If it restores test coverage without flakes, then LGTM. I'm not super happy with how the test suite is designed but I think that is not a blocker.

LGTM. Thanks for so many ongoing fixes to this stuff.
@kennknowles I run fixed tests sequently on my side, several hundreds time in a row, and I didn't see any issues as we had before.
This didn't break it, but I want to get it green or confirm a flaky test to file a bug about.
Thanks for submitting this @aromanenko-dev. I like your idea but it seems a bit lengthy to me. I just did some research and I came across the _Mockito.timeout()_ method. Have you seen it?
Will do, but I'll leave it to a separate PR as adding the check ends up enforcing more changes (for example {} will no longer be allowed)
Indeed Python SDK PostCommit found I was not guarding against not using the Fn API. Fixed, all passes now.
@chamikaramj does this look good to you? I think it's basically ready to merge unless there are any other comments, thanks!

--- Reviewed 2 of 2 files at r1. Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, all discussions resolved, some commit checks failed. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4637#-:-L5ASV1pxigOMnJ5en__:bnfp4nl)*

Hi @aromanenko-dev @kennknowles. During the review of [PR-4661](https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4661) I've discovered that Mockito has the ability to do verifications with timeouts. This way we can simply solve the flaky tests without adding too much logic. What do you think?

The only question that I have is whether I should be putting the FunctionSpec or the SdkFunctionSpec as the payload.

Any ideas @robertwb?

I would like to abolish the ill-defined concepts of sources and sinks, instead having everything be just transforms (and IOs be simply an informal name for transforms used for a particular purpose) - and SDF is part of that vision :) If we need to watch for new Kafka partitions - there needs to be a splittable or stateful DoFn to do that (applied to a PCollection of topics), before the partition-reading SDF. If anything is designated as a "source", it can no longer be placed anywhere except at the very root of the pipeline, and can no longer be data-dependent.

This is also in line with the Fn API where the concept of sources doesn't exist either (or, currently exists on life support but is destined to be deleted) - instead it only has a primitive "impulse" that generates a single empty value to kick off everything else.

Do we have any other options? Would it be difficult to make Flink work properly if some operators at the root shut down but others continue working potentially forever?
This also works for me - I'll leave it up to you two.
Please do a git fix-up and merge commits to single/few commit(s).

@pawel-kaczmarczyk  LGTM. In general, I'm ok with your solution since it contains less boilerplate and easy to understand. Though, it still relies on "_timeout_" approach which, potentially, leave some very small probability of instability. Probably, in the future, we need to rethink the way how to test multithreaded code in `KinesisIO`.
Thank you for fixing this!
@pawel-kaczmarczyk Btw, did you test it running multiple times these tests to make sure that they are not flakey anymore?
I've run it 100 times and it worked every time so 10s timeout seems to be enough for now. Thanks for your review.
Ok jenkins not happy but unrelated, so merging. Thanks again @aromanenko-dev
What is the plan to synchronous gcloud version with the version of the script?

> so there's no reason it can't be changed, though you'll probably want to make it configurable 

A smaller default is fine too. Shall I send a PR to make this and reuse-chance configurable?

@eugene Parquet can be deserialized in several formats including Avro, I
don't think it's a good idea to tie it to Avro, instead users should be
able to use the Parquet read support implementations to map to values of
their choosing be it Avro or Protobuf messages.
